text: Byzantine fault tolerance (BFT) is a property of distributed systems that can reach consensus even when some nodes are faulty or malicious. It uses cryptographic signatures and message broadcasting to ensure agreement.
Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) is an algorithm that achieves BFT in asynchronous systems. It requires 3f+1 nodes to tolerate f faulty nodes and uses a three-phase commitment protocol.

Raft is a consensus algorithm designed for distributed systems that is more understandable than Paxos. It divides the problem into leader election, log replication, and safety, making it easier to implement correctly.

Two-Phase Commit (2PC) is a protocol that ensures all-or-nothing outcomes in distributed transactions. A coordinator sends prepare requests to all participants, then commits or aborts based on their responses.

ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) are crucial for database systems. In distributed systems, achieving all four properties simultaneously is challenging and often involves trade-offs.

The FLP impossibility result proves that no algorithm can guarantee consensus in an asynchronous distributed system where even one process might crash. This has profound implications for distributed system design.
Eventual consistency is a weaker consistency model used in distributed systems where updates are propagated asynchronously. Systems like Cassandra and DynamoDB use this model for high availability.
Quorum-based systems ensure consistency by requiring that reads and writes are acknowledged by a majority of nodes. This provides a middle ground between strong consistency and eventual consistency.
